cab.content: (THIS DOCUMENT IS THE PROPERTY OF HER BRITANNIC MAJESTYlS government secret.P.(55) 24 COPY NO. 6 22nd June, 1955CABINETTHE QUEEN'S SPEECH ON THE OPENINGOF parliament note by the Lord President of the council I circulate, for the consideration of the Cabinet, a draft ofThe Queen's Speech on the Opening of Parliament, In the time available it has not been possible for the Committee to reach complete agreement on all passages in this draft with the Ministers departmentally responsible.In such cases the wording favoured by the responsible Minister has been inserted at this stage.S.\Privy Council Office, S, W. 1.1st June, 1955. THE QUEEN'S SPEECH ON THE OPENINGOF parliament my Government will continue to strive tirelessly for the promotion of peace and progress.2. My Government will maintain and strengthen consultation with theCommonwealth for the fulfilment of our common purposes.3. The economic development of the Commonwealth and Colonieswill be steadily encouraged and My Government will continue to supportthe Colombo Plan.4. My Government look forward to further progress in establishing the British Caribbean Federation.5. In their relations with foreign Powers My Government willresolutely go forward with those policies to which they have already pledgedtheir support. The United Nations, the Atlantic Alliance and the newassociation of We stern European Union will all receive their whole-hearted-operation. They will in all things seek to work in close collaboration with the United States of America.6. Fortified by the growing unity and strength of the free nations.My Government look forward, in a spirit of confidence and goodwill, tofruitful negotiations with the Government of the Soviet Union at the forth-coming Conference.7. My Government welcome the progress which has recently beenmade in the United Nations1 discussions on disarmament and will zealouslymaintain their efforts to reach agreement on a comprehensive disarmamentplan designed to bring peace and security.8. My Government have also warmly welcomed the signature of theState Treaty for the re-establishment of an independent and democraticAustria, the text of which will be presented to you before ratification.9. In consultation with the other Governments concerned, My Govern-ment will continue earnestly to seek a peaceful settlement of the situationin the Formosa Strait.10. My Government will continue their efforts to uphold the Indo-Chinasettlement concluded at Geneva and their co-operation in promoting thepeace, security and prosperity of South East Asia through the regional organisations established for that purpose.11. My Government will ensure that My Forces continue to play their full part in maintaining peace and stability in the world.12. My Ministers will pursue with energy their review of the problemsof Home Defence with particular regard to the measures required to meetnew forms of warfare.Members of the House of Commons13. The Estimates for Public Services will be laid before you in due course.-1- My Lords and Members of the House of Commons14. The full employment of My People will continue to be the first care of My Ministers. To this end they look to the co-operation of all sectionsof industry, commerce and agriculture. They are convinced that in thisway an ever higher standard of living can be secured for the whole nation.15. My Government will continue to study the effects of monopolies and restrictive practices, and will not hesitate to take any action that maybe required in the public interest to deal with abuses in this field.16. My Ministers will encourage the further expansion of industrial production. They will seek powers, consistent with our international obligations and objectives, to defend our industries and agriculture againstunfair trading practices.17, My Government will energetically promote the development of nuclear energy for peaceful purposes.10. It will be the aim of My Ministers to strengthen the balance ofpayments and to extend overseas markets for our goods and services.Together with the other Governments of the Commonwealth and of Europe,and with the Government of the United States of America, they will workfor a further advance towards a free flow of international trade and payments,19. It will be the ceaseless endeavour of My Ministers to combatwaste in public expenditure, and by sound handling of financial affairs to check the dangers of inflation.20. My Ministers recognise the need for maximum economic production from our land to provide ample supplies of food for all My People. Theywill continue, through guaranteed prices and assured markets, to ensure to producers a fair return, and will courage the efficient marketing offood.21, Legislation will be introduced to safeguard the health and providefor the safety and welfare of those employed in agriculture and forestry.2. My Ministers will continue to promote the well-being of the fishing industry and to support the efforts of the White Fish Authority and the herring Industry Board to improve the condition of the fishing fleets and enable them to operate on an efficient basis.23. My Government have already announced a far-reaching programmeof road construction and improvement. They will press on with their plans to reduce danger on the roads and ease the flow of traffic. A measure willbe laid before you to amend the Road Traffic Acts.24. In the light of proposals recently agreed among the Local authority associations My Government are examining the problems of local govern-ment in England and Wales with a view to introducing legislation on thissubject.25. My Ministers will continue to ensure a high rate of house building.They will encourage action to secure the more rapid clearance of slums in both town and country and to relieve urban congestion. They will not hesitate to introduce any legislation which may be found necessary tofurther these objects. 26. In step with the continued expansion in the building and improvementof schools My Government will give close attention to the number and needsof the teaching profession. ^""They will have very much in mind the special requierements of rural areas^/ Secondary schools will be encouraged toprovide a choice of courses; and facilities for technical education will beextended.27. My Ministers will propose amendments to the scheme of super-annuation for teachers in the light of discussions now proceeding withrepresentatives of teachers and local authorities.28. A Bill will be prepared to extend the period during which family allowances are payable for children who remain at school.29. Legislation will be introduced to amend the law of valuation and rating in Scotland in accordance with the recommendations of a departmental Committee; and an inquiry into the working of the arrange-ments for ascertaining Equalisation Grant in Scotland will be made inconsultation with the Associations of Local Authorities.30. You will also be invited to pass a measure to amend the law relating to valuation and rating in England and V/ales.31. Legislation will be proposed to carry out recommendations of theCopyright Committee.32. My Government will proceed with a Bill to enable them to carryout their obligations under the Commonwealth Sugar Agreement, and tobring to an end the present system of state trading in sugar.33. Steps will be taken to extend legal aid to proceedings in county courts in England and Wales, and the jurisdiction of these Courts will beincreased. A measure will also be introduced to set up new criminalcourts at Liverpool and Manchester, and to amend the law relating torecorders and stipendiary magistrates.33. A Committee will be appointed to consider practice and procedure in relation to Administrative Tribunals and quasi judicial enquiries,including those concerning land.34. Further consideration will be given to the problem of the composition of the House of Lords.35. Other meausres will be laid before you in due course.36. I pray that the blessing of Almighty God may rest upon your counsels.J
